Show / Hide Table of Contents

Class FigaroEnv

The handle for a database environment - a collection including support for some or all of caching, locking, logging and transaction subsystems, as well as databases and log files. Methods of the FigaroEnv handle are used to configure the environment as well as to operate on subsystems and databases in the environment.

Inheritance
System.Object
FigaroEnv
Implements
System.IDisposable
Inherited Members
System.Object.ToString()

System.Object.GetHashCode()
System.Object.GetType()
System.Object.MemberwiseClone()
Namespace: Figaro
Assembly: Figaro.dll
Syntax
public sealed class FigaroEnv : IDisposable
Remarks

FigaroEnv handles are free-threaded if the Thread flag is specified to the Open(String, EnvOpenOptions) method when the environment is opened. The FigaroEnv handle should not be closed while any other handle remains open that is using it as a reference. Once either the Close() or Remove(String, EnvironmentRemoveAction) methods are called, the handle may not be accessed again.

Remarks

The constructor allocates memory internally; calling the Close() or Remove(String, EnvironmentRemoveAction) methods will free that memory.

DeadlockDetectPolicy

Gets or sets the deadlock detector to be run whenever a lock conflict occurs, and specify what lock request(s) should be rejected.

Declaration
public DeadlockDetectType DeadlockDetectPolicy { get; set; }
Property Value
Type Description
DeadlockDetectType

The enumeration indicating the type of deadlock policy set in place.
Remarks

As transactions acquire locks on behalf of a single locker ID, rejecting a lock request associated with a transaction normally requires the transaction be aborted.

The DeadlockDetectPolicy property configures a database environment, not only operations performed using the specified FigaroEnv handle.

This property may be set at any time during the life of the application.

MaxFileDescriptors

View Source

MaxFileMapSize

Gets or sets the maximum file size, in bytes, for a file to be mapped into the process address space. If no value is specified, it defaults to 10MB.

Declaration
public ulong MaxFileMapSize { get; set; }
Property Value
Type Description
System.UInt64

The maximum size for a file to be mapped into the process address space.
Remarks

Files that are opened read-only in the pool (that also satisfy a few other criteria) are, by default, mapped into the process address space instead of being copied into the local cache. This can result in better-than-usual performance because available virtual memory is normally much larger than the local cache, and page faults are faster than page copying on many systems. However, it can cause resource starvation in the presence of limited virtual memory, and it can result in immense process sizes in the presence of large databases.

The MaxFileMapSize property configures a database environment, not only operations performed using the specified FigaroEnv handle.

The MaxFileMapSize property may be set at any time during the life of the application.

View Source

MaxLogRegion

MaxLogSize

Gets or sets the maximum size of a single file in the log, in bytes.

Declaration
public uint MaxLogSize { get; set; }
Property Value
Type Description
System.UInt32

The maximum size of a single file in the log, in bytes.

Remarks

Because log sequence number (LSN) file offsets are unsigned four-byte values, the set value may not be larger than the maximum unsigned four-byte value.

When the logging subsystem is configured for on-disk logging, the default size of a log file is 10MB.

When the logging subsystem is configured for in-memory logging, the default size of a log file is 256KB. In addition, the configured log buffer size must be larger than the log file size. (The logging subsystem divides memory configured for in-memory log records into "files", as database environments configured for in-memory log records may exchange log records with other members of a replication group, and those members may be configured to store log records on-disk.) When choosing log buffer and file sizes for in-memory logs, applications should ensure the in-memory log buffer size is large enough that no transaction will ever span the entire buffer, and avoid a state where the in-memory buffer is full and no space can be freed because a transaction that started in the first log "file" is still active.

See Configuring the Logging Subsystem for more information.

The MaxLogSize property sets a database environment, not only operations performed using the specified FigaroEnv handle.

The MaxLogSize property may be set at any time during the life of the application.

If no size is specified by the application, the size last specified for the database region will be used, or if no database region previously existed, the default will be used.

Methods

View Source

AddDataDirectory(String)

Adds the path of a directory to be used as the location of the access method database files. Paths specified to the Open(String, EnvOpenOptions) function will be searched relative to this path. Paths set using this method are additive, and specifying more than one will result in each specified directory being searched for database files. If any directories are specified, created database files will always be created in the first path specified.

If no database directories are specified, database files must be named either by absolute paths or relative to the environment home directory. This method configures operations performed using the specified FigaroEnv handle, not all operations performed on the underlying database environment.

This method may not be called after the Open(String, EnvOpenOptions) method is called. If the database environment already exists when Open(String, EnvOpenOptions) is called, the information specified to this method must be consistent with the existing environment or corruption can occur.

Declaration
public void AddDataDirectory(string dataDirectory)
Parameters
Type Name Description
System.String dataDirectory

A directory to be used as a location for database files.
View Source

Close()

Closes the Figaro environment, freeing any allocated resources and closing any underlying subsystems.

Declaration
public void Close()
Remarks

The FigaroEnv handle should not be closed while any other handle that refers to it is not yet closed; for example, database environment handles must not be closed while database handles remain open, or transactions in the environment have not yet been committed or aborted.

Where the environment was initialized with the InitLock flag, calling Close() does not release any locks still held by the closing process, providing functionality for long-lived locks.

Where the environment was initialized with the InitMemoryBufferPool flag, calling Close() implies calls to DbMpoolFile.close for any remaining open files in the memory pool that were returned to this process by calls to DbMpoolFile.open. It does not imply a call to DbMpoolFile.sync for those files.

info

The DbMPoolFile referenced is used internally by the underlying environment object, and not explicitly implemented as a .NET object in this library version.

Where the environment was initialized with the InitTransaction or TransactionDefaults flags, calling Close() aborts any unresolved transactions. Applications should not depend on this behavior for transactions involving Figaro databases; all such transactions should be explicitly resolved. The problem with depending on this semantic is that aborting an unresolved transaction involving database operations requires a database handle. Because the database handles should have been closed before calling Close(), it will not be possible to abort the transaction, and recovery will have to be run on the Figaro environment before further operations are done.

In multi-threaded applications, only a single thread may call Close().

After Close() has been called, regardless of its return, the Figaro environment handle may not be accessed again.

See Also
EnvOpenOptions
View Source

Dispose()

Performs application-defined tasks associated with freeing, releasing, or resetting unmanaged resources.

Declaration
public void Dispose()
View Source

FailCheck()

Checks for threads of control (either a true thread or a process) that have exited while manipulating data structures, while holding a logical database lock, or with an unresolved transaction (that is, a transaction that was never aborted or committed).

Declaration
public bool FailCheck()
Returns
Type Description
System.Boolean

true if recovery needs to be run against the environment; otherwise, false is returned.
Remarks

Applications calling the FailCheck() method must have already enabled the IsAliveEnabled property, and must have configured the database environment using the ThreadCount property.

If FailCheck() determines a thread of control exited while holding database read locks, it will release those locks. If FailCheck() determines a thread of control exited with an unresolved transaction, the transaction will be aborted. In either of these cases, FailCheck() will return false and the application may continue to use the database environment.

In either of these cases, the FailCheck() method will also report the process and thread IDs associated with any released locks or aborted transactions. The information is printed to a specified output channel (see the MessageEventEnabled method for more information).

If FailCheck() determines a thread of control has exited such that database environment recovery is required, it will return true. In this case, the application should not continue to use the database environment. For a further description as to the actions the application should take when this failure occurs, see Handling failure in Data Store and Concurrent Data Store applications, and Handling failure in Transactional Data Store applications.

The FailCheck() method may not be called before the Open(String, EnvOpenOptions) method has been called.

See Also
Open(String, EnvOpenOptions)
IsAliveEnabled
ThreadCount
View Source

FileIdReset(String, Boolean)

Allows database files to be copied, and then the copy used in the same database environment as the original.

Declaration
public void FileIdReset(string file, bool encrypted)
Parameters
Type Name Description
System.String file

The name of the physical file in which new file IDs are to be created.
System.Boolean encrypted

If true, indicates the file contains encrypted databases.
Remarks

All databases contain an ID string used to identify the database in the database environment cache. If a physical database file is copied, and used in the same environment as another file with the same ID strings, corruption can occur. The FileIdReset(String, Boolean) method creates new ID strings for all of the databases in the physical file.

FileIdReset(String, Boolean) modifies the physical file, in-place. Applications should not reset IDs in files that are currently in use.

The FileIdReset(String, Boolean) method may be called at any time during the life of the application.

GetCacheMax()

Gets the maximum cache size and stores it in the EnvCacheSize structure, containing the total size in gigabytes and bytes.

Declaration
public EnvCacheSize GetCacheMax()
Returns
Type Description
EnvCacheSize

An EnvCacheSize structure containing the configured size of the environment cache.
Remarks

The specified size is rounded to the nearest multiple of the cache region size, which is the initial cache size divided by the number of regions specified to the GetCacheSize() method. If no value is specified, it defaults to the initial cache size.

The GetCacheMax() method may be called at any time during the life of the application.

GetTimeout(EnvironmentTimeoutType)

Gets the timeout values for the specified EnvironmentTimeoutType.

Declaration
public uint GetTimeout(EnvironmentTimeoutType timeoutType)
Parameters
Type Name Description
EnvironmentTimeoutType timeoutType

The timeout type to look up.
Returns
Type Description
System.UInt32

The timeout value, in microseconds.
Remarks

All timeouts are checked whenever a thread of control blocks on a lock or when deadlock detection is performed.

In the case of Lock, the lock is one requested explicitly through the Lock subsystem interfaces. In the case of Transaction, the lock is one requested on behalf of a transaction. In either case, it may be a lock requested by the database access methods underlying the application.

As timeouts are only checked when the lock request first blocks or when deadlock detection is performed, the accuracy of the timeout depends on how often deadlock detection is performed.

See Also
EnvironmentTimeoutType
SetTimeout(UInt32, EnvironmentTimeoutType)
View Source

LockDetect(DeadlockDetectType)

Runs one iteration of the deadlock detector. The deadlock detector traverses the lock table and marks one of the participating lock requesters for rejection in each deadlock it finds.

The method either throws an exception that encapsulates a non-zero error value on failure, and returns the number of lock requests that were rejected.

Declaration
public uint LockDetect(DeadlockDetectType detectType)
Parameters
Type Name Description
DeadlockDetectType detectType

The parameter specifying which lock requests to reject.
Returns
Type Description
System.UInt32

The number of rejected lock requests.
View Source

LogArchive(LogArchiveOptions)

View Source

LSNReset(String, Boolean)

The LSNReset(String, Boolean) method allows database files to be moved from one transactional database environment to another.

Declaration
public void LSNReset(string file, bool dbEncrypt)
Parameters
Type Name Description
System.String file

The name of the physical file in which LSNs are to be cleared.
System.Boolean dbEncrypt

Set to true if the file contains encrypted databases.
Remarks

Database pages in transactional database environments contain references to the environment's log files (that is, log sequence numbers, or LSNs). Copying or moving a database file from one database environment to another, and then modifying it, can result in data corruption if the LSNs are not first cleared.

Note that LSNs should be reset before moving or copying the database file into a new database environment, rather than moving or copying the database file and then resetting the LSNs. Figaro has consistency checks that may be triggered if an application calls LSNReset(String, Boolean) on a database in a new environment when the database LSNs still reflect the old environment.

The LSNReset(String, Boolean) method modifies the physical file, in-place. Applications should not reset LSNs in files that are currently in use.

The LSNReset(String, Boolean) method may be called at any time during the life of the application.

View Source

Open(String, EnvOpenOptions)

Opens a Figaro environment. It provides a structure for creating a consistent environment for processes using one or more of the features of Berkeley DB.

Declaration
public void Open(string dbHome, EnvOpenOptions envOpenOptions)
Parameters
Type Name Description
System.String dbHome

The database environment's home directory. For more information on the home directory, and filename resolution in general, see @file-naming.md. The environment variable DB_HOME may be used as the path of the database home, as described in @file-naming.md. When using a Unicode build on Windows (the default), the dbHome argument will be interpreted as a UTF-8 string, which is equivalent to ASCII for Latin characters.
EnvOpenOptions envOpenOptions

The EnvOpenOptions parameter.
Remarks
implementnotes

If the InitConcurrentDataStore flag is specified, the AllConcurrentDatabases flag is automatically set. This flag is required for the underlying Berkeley DB XML database configuration.

See Also
EnvOpenOptions
AllConcurrentDatabases

Destroys a Figaro environment if it is not currently in use.

Declaration

Parameters
Type Name Description
System.String dbHome

The database environment's home directory. For more information on the home directory, and filename resolution in general, see @file-naming.md. The environment variable DB_HOME may be used as the path of the database home, as described in @file-naming.md. When using a Unicode build on Windows (the default), the dbHome argument will be interpreted as a UTF-8 string, which is equivalent to ASCII for Latin characters.

SetCacheMax(EnvCacheSize)

Sets the maximum cache size.

Declaration
public void SetCacheMax(EnvCacheSize size)
Parameters
Type Name Description
EnvCacheSize size

The desired maximum cache size.
Remarks

The specified size is rounded to the nearest multiple of the cache region size, which is the initial cache size divided by the number of regions specified to the SetCacheSize(EnvCacheSize, Int32) method. If no value is specified, it defaults to the initial cache size.

This method configures a database environment, not only operations performed using the specified FigaroEnv handle.

Setting this value in an empty FigaroEnv may throw an exception. If this occurs, set the cache size first with a call to SetCacheSize(EnvCacheSize, Int32).

This method may be called at any time during the life of the application.

View Source

SetCacheSize(EnvCacheSize, Int32)

Set the size of the shared memory buffer pool - that is, the cache. The cache should be the size of the normal working data set of the application, with some small amount of additional memory for unusual situations. (Note: the working set is not the same as the number of pages accessed simultaneously, and is usually much larger.)

Declaration
public void SetCacheSize(EnvCacheSize size, int cacheCount)
Parameters
Type Name Description
EnvCacheSize size

The EnvCacheSize structure specifying the size of the file to be mapped into the process address space.
System.Int32 cacheCount

The number of caches to create. Each cache specified will have a size equal to the size parameter divided by this number.
Remarks

The default cache size is 256KB, and may not be specified as less than 20KB. Any cache size less than 500MB is automatically increased by 25% to account for buffer pool overhead; cache sizes larger than 500MB are used as specified. The maximum size of a single cache is 4GB on 32-bit systems and 10TB on 64-bit systems. (All sizes are in powers-of-two, that is, 256KB is 218 not 256,000.) For information on tuning the database cache size, see Selecting a Cache Size.

It is possible to specify caches to Figaro large enough they cannot be allocated contiguously on some architectures. If the cache count (set through SetCacheSize(EnvCacheSize, Int32)) is 0 or 1, the cache will be allocated contiguously in memory. If it is greater than 1, the cache will be split across nseparate regions, where the region size is equal to the initial cache size divided by the cache count.

The memory pool may be resized by calling SetCacheSize(EnvCacheSize, Int32) after the environment is open. The supplied size will be rounded to the nearest multiple of the region size and may not be larger than the maximum size configured with SetCacheMax(EnvCacheSize).

The SetCacheSize(EnvCacheSize, Int32) method configures a database environment, not only operations performed using the specified FigaroEnv handle.

The SetCacheSize(EnvCacheSize, Int32) method may be called at any time during the life of the application.

See Also
GetCacheCount()
View Source

SetEnvironmentTransactionCheckpoint(Boolean, UInt32, UInt32)

Write a checkpoint to and flush the log at these set intervals.

Declaration
public void SetEnvironmentTransactionCheckpoint(bool force, uint minutes, uint logKilobytes)
Parameters
Type Name Description
System.Boolean force

If true, forces a checkpoint record, even if there has been no activity since the last checkpoint.
System.UInt32 minutes

If nonzero, a checkpoint will be performed if more than the specified minutes have passed since the last checkpoint.
System.UInt32 logKilobytes

If nonzero, a checkpoint will be performed if more than the specified kilobytes have been written to the log file since the last checkpoint.
Remarks

If there has been any logging activity in the database environment since the last checkpoint, the SetEnvironmentTransactionCheckpoint(Boolean, UInt32, UInt32) method flushes the underlying memory pool, writes a checkpoint record to the log, and then flushes the log.

SetErrorFile(String)

When set, additional information regarding error information will be streamed to this location.

Declaration
public void SetErrorFile(string pathAndFile)
Parameters
Type Name Description
System.String pathAndFile

fully-qualified path the file to write error event information into.
Remarks

When an error occurs in the Figaro library, an exception is thrown or an error return value is returned by the interface. In some cases, however, the exception or returned value may be insufficient to completely describe the cause of the error, especially during initial application debugging.

This error logging enhancement does not slow performance or significantly increase application size, and may be run during normal operation as well as during application debugging.

This method can be set at any time during the life of the application.

SetLockPartitions(UInt32)

Set the number of lock table partitions in the environment.

Declaration
public void SetLockPartitions(uint partitions)
Parameters
Type Name Description
System.UInt32 partitions

The number of lock table partitions.
Remarks

The default value is 10 times the number of CPUs on the system if there is more than one CPU. Increasing the number of partitions can provide for greater throughput on a system with multiple CPUs and more than one thread contending for the lock manager. On single processor systems more than one partition may increase the overhead of the lock manager. Systems often report threading contexts as CPUs. If your system does this, set the number of partitions to 1 to get optimal performance.

View Source

SetLogBufferSize(UInt32)

Sets the size of the in-memory log buffer, in bytes.

Declaration
public void SetLogBufferSize(uint size)
Parameters
Type Name Description
System.UInt32 size

The new in-memory log buffer size, in bytes.
Remarks

When the logging subsystem is configured for on-disk logging, the default size of the in-memory log buffer is approximately 32KB. Log information is stored in-memory until the storage space fills up or transaction commit forces the information to be flushed to stable storage. In the presence of long-running transactions or transactions producing large amounts of data, larger buffer sizes can increase throughput.

When the logging subsystem is configured for in-memory logging, the default size of the in-memory log buffer is 1MB. Log information is stored in-memory until the storage space fills up or transaction abort or commit frees up the memory for new transactions. In the presence of long-running transactions or transactions producing large amounts of data, the buffer size must be sufficient to hold all log information that can accumulate during the longest running transaction. When choosing log buffer and file sizes for in-memory logs, applications should ensure the in-memory log buffer size is large enough that no transaction will ever span the entire buffer, and avoid a state where the in-memory buffer is full and no space can be freed because a transaction that started in the first log "file" is still active.

SetLogBufferSize(UInt32) configures a database environment, not only operations performed using the specified FigaroEnv handle.

This method should not be called after the Open(String, EnvOpenOptions) method is called. If the database environment already exists when Open(String, EnvOpenOptions) is set, any changes to this property will be ignored.

View Source

SetLogDirectory(String)

Sets the path of a directory to be used as the location of logging files. Log files created by the Log Manager subsystem will be created in this directory.

Declaration
public void SetLogDirectory(string path)
Parameters
Type Name Description
System.String path

The path of the directory for the location of log files.
Remarks

If no logging directory is specified, log files are created in the environment home directory. See @file-naming.md for more information.

For the greatest degree of recoverability from system or application failure, database files and log files should be located on separate physical devices.

SetLogDirectory configures operations performed using the specified FigaroEnv handle, not all operations performed on the underlying database environment.

This method should not be called after the Open(String, EnvOpenOptions) method. If the database environment already exists when Open(String, EnvOpenOptions) is called, the information specified to SetLogDirectory(String) must be consistent with the existing environment or corruption can occur.

SetMaxLogRegion(UInt32)

Set the size of the underlying logging area of the Figaro environment, in bytes.

Declaration
public void SetMaxLogRegion(uint size)
Parameters
Type Name Description
System.UInt32 size

The maximum log region size, in bytes.
Remarks

By default, or if the value is set to 0, the default size is approximately 60KB. The log region is used to store filenames, and so may need to be increased in size if a large number of files will be opened and registered with the specified Figaro BDB environment's log manager.

SetMaxMutexes(UInt32)

Configures the maximum number of mutexes to allocate.

Declaration
public void SetMaxMutexes(uint mutexes)
Parameters
Type Name Description
System.UInt32 mutexes

The maximum number of mutexes.
Remarks

The underlying database system allocates a default number of mutexes based on the initial configuration of the database environment. That default calculation may be too small if the application has an unusual need for mutexes (for example, if the application opens an unexpectedly large number of databases) or too large (if the application is trying to minimize its memory footprint).

The SetMaxMutexes(UInt32) method is used to specify an absolute number of mutexes to allocate.

See Also
MaxMutexes

SetMaxSequentialWriteOperations(UInt32, UInt32)

Limits the number of sequential write operations scheduled by the library when flushing dirty pages from the cache.

Declaration
public void SetMaxSequentialWriteOperations(uint writes, uint sleepMicroseconds)
Parameters
Type Name Description
System.UInt32 writes

The maximum number of write operations. Specify 0 for an unlimited number.
System.UInt32 sleepMicroseconds

The number of microseconds the thread of control should pause before scheduling further write operations. It must be specified as an unsigned 32-bit number of microseconds, limiting the maximum pause to roughly 71 minutes.
See Also
MaxSequentialWriteOperationsSleep
SetMaxSequentialWriteOperations(UInt32, UInt32)
View Source

SetMaxTransactions(UInt16)

Sets the maximum supported transactions in a Figaro database environment.

Declaration
public void SetMaxTransactions(ushort value)
Parameters
Type Name Description
System.UInt16 value

The maximum number of transactions.
Remarks

Configure the Figaro database environment to support maximum specified active transactions. This value bounds the size of the memory allocated for transactions. Child transactions are counted as active until they either commit or abort.

Transactions that update multi-version databases are not freed until the last page version that the transaction created is flushed from cache. This means that applications using multi-version concurrency control may need a transaction for each page in cache, in the extreme case.

When all of the memory available in the database environment for transactions is in use, calls to begin transactions will fail (until some active transactions complete). If this interface is never called, the database environment is configured to support at least 100 active transactions.

See Also
MaxTransactions
View Source

Declaration

Parameters
Type Name Description
System.UInt32 align

The mutex alignment, in bytes. The mutex alignment must be a power-of-two value.
Remarks

It is sometimes advantageous to align mutexes on specific byte boundaries in order to minimize cache line collisions. The SetMutexAlign(UInt32) method specifies an alignment for mutexes allocated by the database subsystem.

The number of database environment threads.

Must be set prior to opening the database environment if the FailCheck() method will be used. Setting the thread count does not set the maximum number of threads but is used to determine memory sizing and the thread control block reclamation policy.

This property cannot be set after the Open(String, EnvOpenOptions) method has been called.

SetTimeout(UInt32, EnvironmentTimeoutType)

Sets the timeout values for the requested EnvironmentTimeoutType.

Declaration
public void SetTimeout(uint microseconds, EnvironmentTimeoutType timeoutType)
Parameters
Type Name Description
System.UInt32 microseconds

The number of microseconds to set the timeout to.
EnvironmentTimeoutType timeoutType

The timeout type to set.
Remarks

All timeouts are checked whenever a thread of control blocks on a lock or when deadlock detection is performed.

In the case of Lock, the lock is one requested explicitly through the Lock subsystem interfaces. In the case of Transaction, the lock is one requested on behalf of a transaction. In either case, it may be a lock requested by the database access methods underlying the application.

As timeouts are only checked when the lock request first blocks or when deadlock detection is performed, the accuracy of the timeout depends on how often deadlock detection is performed.

See Also
EnvironmentTimeoutType
GetTimeout(EnvironmentTimeoutType)
View Source

TraceError(String, Object[])

Trace custom information into the FigaroEnv error trace output.

Declaration
public void TraceError(string message, params object[] args)
Parameters
Type Name Description
System.String message

The format string of the error message.
System.Object[] args

Format string arguments.
Remarks

This function allows developers to trace System.String.Format(System.String,System.Object[])-style formatted strings into the Figaro error output stream configured for the FigaroEnvinstance. These streams can be either file-based (SetErrorFile(String)), event-driven (ErrEventEnabled) or the default (stderr). You can also set a custom error prefix (ErrorPrefix) to help catalog and categorize error output.

note

There is no equivalent method for the message output.

OnErr

Raises an event when an error condition is raised within the Figaro library.

Declaration
public event EventHandler<ErrEventArgs> OnErr
Event Type
Type Description
System.EventHandler<ErrEventArgs>
Remarks

When an error occurs in the Figaro library, an exception is thrown or an error return value is returned by the interface. In some cases, however, the errno value may be insufficient to completely describe the cause of the error, especially during initial application debugging.

The OnErr event is used to enhance the mechanism for reporting error messages to the application. In some cases, when an error occurs, Figaro will raise the event with additional error information. It is up to the event caller to display the error message in an appropriate manner.

Setting ErrEventEnabled to false disables this event.

Alternatively, you can use the ErrorFile property to to display the additional information via a file stream. You should not mix these approaches.

This error-logging enhancement does not slow performance or significantly increase application size, and may be run during normal operation as well as during application debugging.

The OnErr event configures operations performed using the specified FigaroEnv handle, not all operations performed on the underlying database environment.

The OnErr event may be called at any time during the life of the application.

See Also
ErrEventEnabled
ErrorFile
FigaroEnv
View Source

FigaroEnv
View Source

OnMessage

Raises the event when informational conditions are raised within the FigaroEnv.

Declaration
public event EventHandler<MsgEventArgs> OnMessage
Event Type
Type Description
System.EventHandler<MsgEventArgs>
Remarks

There are interfaces in the Figaro library which either directly output informational messages or statistical information, or configure the library to output such messages when performing other operations, for example, SetVerbose(VerboseOption, Boolean) and PrintDefaultStatistics(StatPrintOptions).

The OnMessage event is used to pass these messages to the application, and Figaro raise the event for each message. It is up to the event caller to display the message in an appropriate manner.

Setting MessageEventEnabled to true enables the event; setting it to false disables the event.

Alternatively, you can use the MessageFile property to display the messages via an output file.

The OnMessage event may be called at any time during the life of the application.

View Source

System.EventHandler<ProcessEventArgs>

Setting ProcessEventEnabled to true enables the event; setting ProcessEventEnabled to false disables the event.

The OnProcess event may be called at any time during the life of the application.

ProcessEventEnabled
FigaroEnv

OnProgress

An event raised to report Figaro operation progress.

Declaration
public event EventHandler<ProgressEventArgs> OnProgress
Event Type
Type Description
System.EventHandler<ProgressEventArgs>
Remarks

Some operations performed by the database library can take non-trivial amounts of time. OnProgress event can be used by applications to monitor progress within these operations. When an operation is likely to take a long time, Figaro will raise the event with progress information.

It is up to the event caller to display this information in an appropriate manner.

Setting ProgressEventEnabled to true enables this event; setting ProgressEventEnabled to false disables this event.

The OnProgress method configures operations performed using the specified handle.

This event may be called at any time during the life of the application.

See Also
ProgressEventEnabled
